newsitem.title: USA: Commercial rents jump in first half of 1996 - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Commercial rents jump in first half of 1996 - WSJ.

text.p: Rents for U.S. commercial office space soared more than 10 percent in the first half of the year, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.
According to a study from CB Commercial Real Estate Group Inc, the six-month increase was the greatest since 1980 and was spurred by a lack of new construction.
The average annual rent nationwide reached $19.57 a square foot in June, up from $18.11 a square foot six months earlier, the study said.
Rents may keep climbing through 1997 as demand continues to grow, said Ray Torto, economist at the Torto Wheaton Research unit of CB Commercial.

He estimated that U.S. businesses would occupy an additional 50 million square feet of office space this year but only 15 million square feet of new space will be built. Next year, he sees new construction rising to 30 million square feet, but it is still expected to trail the rise in demand, the newspaper said.
Rent increases were strongest in the Midwest and West, and less pronounced in the Northeast.
